description: {"blocks":[{"key":"au6fp","text":"The aim of this protocol is to learn how to prepare, evaluate and optimize a plant chromatin sample to produce a proximity ligated sample ready for NGS library preparation. We introduce several quality checks along the process to avoid wasting precious material or time working with a suboptimal sample (quality and quantity-wise). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9n0b3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

groups.title: Protist Research to Optimize Tools in Genetics (PROT-G)
High molecular weight DNA extraction from all kingdoms

guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"8pkr8","text":"Every sample brings a different challenge and no chromatin protocol is universal. It is recommended to practice with a less precious sample before attempting the preparation of the final Hi-C library. There are a few commercial kits available to prepare Hi-C libraries and perform well under most circumstances, especially since often they have good technical support to help you along the way. This protocol describes an in vitro enzymatic fragmentation of plant chromatin and aims to help understand the importance of QC steps along the process.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89vgn","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c8o1o","text":"Ideally, the chromatin fragmentation should be random, using DNase I, but in practice, this approach can take some time to optimize and if your sample size is limited you may consider using a 4-base restriction enzyme, selected based on the genome's GC content. Or you could also use a mix of two or more 4-base restriction enzymes to target as many sites as possible, either by having a different restriction site or a different methylation sensitivity. Although it is easier to control a restriction enzyme digestion, beware that the genome coverage is reduced, compared to a randomly fragmented chromatin sample. We strongly recommend to perform digestion tests on nuclear gDNA preps with several restriction enzymes until you find a combination that will produce an even digestion profile.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":199,"length":18}],"data":{}},{"key":"30jgi","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dfk8d","text":"Using a biotinylated bridge to mark the contact ends adds extra steps and some assurance that the contacts detected are real, but you could also omit this step and fill in the 5'-end overhangs with biotinylated dNTPs. Beware the length of the carbon chains that links the biotin to the nucleotide (the standard is 6 carbon atoms, used in this protocol) has an impact on how well it will bind to the streptavidin molecule. The longer the carbon chain, the more efficient the binding.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"mck8","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fpoon","text":"If you have trouble isolating a clean nuclei pellet, you could purify it with a Percoll gradient, as described here. The wash volumes of the chromatin bound to magnetic beads can be increased if the sample is hard to clean, or extra washes can be implemented too. The lysis buffer volume can also be increased to reduce the amount of contaminants even before starting the chromatin washes.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":111,"length":4}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"71AB85B0046F11ECACA6A310B4CB88A7","url":"https://enzymefinder.neb.com/#!/main#nebheader"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"94D57660FBB211EB9A21BDBDB404C279","url":"https://www.protocols.io/view/plant-nuclei-enrichment-for-chromatin-capture-base-8vehw3e"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7kf86","text":"The amount of DNA in the nuclei sample allows you to estimate the DNA yield per tube and per gram of tissue","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jai3","text":"The lysate should produce intact DNA, with same profile as your nuclei QC sample described in  . manipulation","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":94,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":94,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"f66oj","text":"The most of the smear is ≤ 300 bp for all dilutions (or time points - see step case option), the sample was over digested. Repeat the DNase I dilution series but incubate the digestion for 30 min only. If you did a time series   use a 0.005 U/μL dilution of DNase I","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":24,"length":8},{"style":"bold","offset":107,"length":13},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":107,"length":13}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":226,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"6b3ml","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5tn31","text":"If most of the smear is ≥ 2500 bp, the sample was under digested. Before repeating or modifying the chromatin prep, check that the DNase I stock is working correctly. Perform a control digestion of 1 µg of Lambda DNA, 20 min only, in 1X DNase I buffer + 10 mM MnCl2, 0.02 U DNase I, in a total volume of 20 μL, 37ºC. Stop the reaction with 1 μL 0.5 M EDTA pH, add 4 μL 6X gel loading buffer and load it all in a 1% agarose gel and include an aliquot of undigested Lambda DNA as control (1X TAE, 140 V, 30 min, stain the gel with SybrSafe after the run or add it directly on the gel). If the test shows no digestion, buy a new DNase I stock (with MnCl2)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":24,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":50,"length":14},{"style":"bold","offset":403,"length":4},{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":50,"length":14},{"style":"sub","offset":264,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":650,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"388mu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f1am","text":"If the under digested result is accompanied by a high DNA yield (\u003e5 µg), QC the lysate again and make sure you only use 2 μg for the chromatin capture step","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":65,"length":5},{"style":"bold","offset":120,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"gotostep","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"90A7D3B0F8BC11EBB12CE5AF2B3061F2","id":0,"step_guid":"E20DF170F66011EB9689CF8DD4AC8647","title":"Nuclei prep"}},"1":{"type":"gotostep","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"D2ABD9F0F8BC11EBB12CE5AF2B3061F2","id":0,"step_guid":"B8D706E0F66D11EB9689CF8DD4AC8647","title":"step case"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"co4vt","text":"We have tested this protocol on several species and although not all of them showed ideal digestions and IMLC profiles (see step case below) the MiSeq QC run produced usable libraries.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"p9be","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"26n80","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dr6rh","text":"The sea urchin and bat samples included in this section were grounded in liquid nitrogen, washed and resuspended in 1X PBS before crosslinking. After quenching the formaldehyde with 1X Wash buffer, the cells were filtered through a 200 μm cell strainer and collected by centrifugation. The myna bird blood cells were defrosted in 1X TE pH 7.5, 100 mM EDTA as soon as they were taken out of the -80ºC freezer, spun down, washed with 1X PBS twice before crosslinking and processed as the other animal samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2kfln","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8q5vd","text":"The table below shows the expected yields along the protocol across 5 different plants.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7e0cq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ji1s","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"a3dkm","text":"It is crucial to use no more than 100 ng of IMLC-illumina sample for the streptavidin magnetic bead capture because not all of it will be captured. Under the conditions described in this method, about 50 ng of the initial 100 ng of IMLC-illumina library is bound to the streptavidin beads. It is possible that by using a longer linker connecting the biotin hapten to the Bridge (+) strand, the steric hindrance might be avoided.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fo6n5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a9236","text":"The cases.title: Library amplification test
cases.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"c6gnd","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":0,"length":1,"key":0}],"data":{}},{"key":"bl9ni","text":"By using increasing amounts of library as template for the amplification at 12 cycles, the fragment distribution and their abundance shifts. For large amounts of template, a reduction of number of cycles is recommended. Although Dynabeads M270 beads don't seem to interfere with PCR, it is best to use the minimal amount of template. Setting up 5 PCR reactions makes pipetting the captured library a lot easier and produces enough amplicons for a double size selection. If using a different DNA polymerase master mix, do a test first to ensure a successful amplification.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"offset":264,"length":9,"key":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8r0f6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2qtdv","text":"After a double size selection (0.5X/0.3X) the average fragment size shifts to 670 bp.
